awd_titl_txt: An Adaptive Partition-based Approach for Solving Large-Scale Stochastic Programs
awd_abstract_narration:
Stochastic programs are popular models for problems requiring optimization under uncertainty. Stochastic programs are challenging to solve, especially when uncertainty characterization relies on a large number of scenarios. Consequently, both scenario decomposition and scenario reduction (clustering and aggregation) techniques are used to reduce computational burden. The latter are performed either in a heuristic manner, or in a way that does not utilize information from intermediate solutions. This project's objective is to advance a computational framework based on partitioning the scenario set adaptively during the solution process. If successful, the technique can be potentially integrated into existing algorithms and software. By enabling faster computation, and in some cases making it possible to solve larger problem instances, the project has the potential to impact a whole host of applications requiring optimization under uncertainty. 

The adaptive partition-based framework will provide a mechanism to aggregate information from scenario sub-problems, by replacing the entire scenario set with an adaptively constructed partition of scenarios. If successful, this will lead to an algorithmic way to coordinate the efforts between approximating the distribution and optimization. The approach will integrate both the optimal (static) scenario reduction technique and the regularized cutting-plane method with inexact oracles in the context of stochastic programs. The developed algorithms will address two-stage and multi-stage stochastic linear programs as well as stochastic integer programs.

por.por_cntn:
Stochastic programming has established itself as an indispensable quantitative tool to support decision making under uncertainty in many application areas. The research objective of this project is to investigate a novel adaptive partition-based computational framework for solving large-scale stochastic programs, so as to impact a whole host of applications requiring optimization under uncertainty. We have achieved this main objective with the following major outcomes:

First, we have established an adaptive partition?-based level decomposition framework for two?-stage stochastic linear programs with fixed recourse. In particular, we have established the theoretical convergence results of the proposed approach and performed an extensive computational experiment to validate its empirical performance. in both theoretical and computational aspects. On the theoretical side, we show that for two-stage stochastic linear programs with fixed recourse, there exists a sufficient partition whose size is independent of number of scenarios. On the computational side, we show that adaptive partition-based level decomposition performs significantly better than the standard cutting-plane methods such as the L-shaped method with or without the partition-based framework and the level method without the partition-based framework. This framework has also been extended to solve two?-stage stochastic integer programs with continuous recourse, where the adaptive partitions are integrated with the branch?-and-?cut algorithm for solving the master problem formulated as an integer program.

Second, we have employed the proposed adaptive partition-based approach to reduce the computational burden of the stochastic dual dynamic programming (SDDP) algorithm for large-scale multi-stage stochastic programs. More specifically, a partition-based formulation (of any given non-leaf node of a scenario tree) corresponds to a relaxation of children-node subproblems, obtained by aggregating variables and constraints according to a scenario partition. We have utilized this relaxation in two different ways: (i) utilizing the adaptive partition-based approach as a catalyst in a pre-processing stage which is then followed by the SDDP algorithm, and a sequence of provisional partitions is exploited to generate valid and coarse cuts to enhance the progress of the standard SDDP algorithm; (ii) integrating cut generation of various efforts (and thus, quality) within the SDDP framework. Numerical results have shown that significant improvement over the standard SDDP algorithm can be achieved in terms of the algorithmic progress.

Third, we have developed an adaptive sequential sampling framework, a unified framework for performing sequential sampling together with adaptive partition-based approaches for solving large-scale stochastic programs. An asymptotically optimal sample size schedule has been developed and validated in an extensive numerical study on two-stage stochastic linear programs. The success of adaptive sequential sampling framework largely attributes to the adaptability in solving each sample average approximation (SAA) problem only imprecisely to an appropriately chosen error tolerance, and the use of warm starts when solving these SAA problems, enabled by the scenario partitions found in prior iterations. A much deeper theoretical understanding on the superiority of the computational performance has been obtained.

Finally, we have attempted to extend the use of the SDDP framework for multi-stage stochastic programming (MSP) in the rolling-horizon (RH) settings. A common approach to tackle MSP problems with a large number of stages is an RH procedure, where one solves a sequence of MSP problems with a smaller number of stages. This leads to a delicate issue of how many stages to include in the smaller problems used in the RH procedure. We have attempted to address this issue for both finite and infinite horizon MSP problems where the stochastic process is assumed to be stationary. For the infinite horizon case with discounts, similar to the well-known results in the Markov Decision Process (MDP) literature, we derive a bound which can be used to prescribe a sufficient number of stages. For the finite horizon case, we propose a heuristic approach from the perspective of approximate dynamic programming to provide a sufficient number of stages for each roll in the RH procedure. Our preliminary numerical experiments on a hydrothermal power generation planning problem have shown the promise of the proposed approaches and have set a stage for further research on trading off the approximation error (due to the use of scenario partitions) and the optimality error (due to the horizon truncation).

The outcomes of this project can benefit both researchers and practitioners by pushing the state-of-the-art solution methodology for stochastic programming models arising in various applications. The results of research outcomes have been incorporated into new PhD-level courses "Optimization under uncertainty" in both Virginia Commonwealth University and Clemson University. The outcomes of this project have been disseminated to other researchers and practitioners by six journal papers, three conference proceedings, three PhD dissertations, three open-source software packages, and more than ten invited seminar and conference talks. The project has supported three PhD students in operations research and two undergraduate STEM students through the REU program, including an underrepresented minority student and a woman student.
